translated: Verses of the Elder Monks 16.10
Verses of the Elders🔽The Twentieth Chapter
The First Chapter
The Elder Pārāpariya
A thought occurred to the monk
in the great forest in bloom;
To one who was sitting alone,
in seclusion, in jhāna:
“In a different way, when the Lord of the World
was standing, the supreme man;
The practice of the monks was one way,
but now it is seen in a different way.
A protection from cold and wind,
a covering for shame and the private parts;
They ate in moderation,
being content with whatever was available.
Whether it was fine or coarse,
whether it was little or much;
They ate for the purpose of sustenance,
not greedy, not infatuated.
With regard to requisites for life,
medicine, and other requirements;
They were not very eager,
as they were for the destruction of the pollutants.
In the wilderness, at the foot of trees,
in caves, in grottoes;
Following seclusion,

analyzed: tad parāyaṇā  nīcā niviṭṭhā subharā  mudū atthaddha mānasā
translated: they lived, having that as their highest aim.🔽They were humble, well-behaved, easy to correct,🔽gentle, with a sense of shame,
not envious, not talkative,
with a sense of what ought to be done, following the sense.
Then it was inspiring,
Gone, eaten, used up,
Like a drop of oil on water,
Was the way of life.
All the cankers are destroyed,
The great meditators, the greatly beneficial,🔽The Elders are now extinguished,
Now there are few like them.
Of wholesome states,
And through the destruction of wisdom,
The Jina’s Dispensation,

analyzed: lujjate jina sāsana  pāpakānam ca dhammāna  kilesānam ca yaḥ u tu
translated: Which has all the best aspects, is decaying.🔽Of bad states,🔽And of the defilements, which are
The conditions, those who are established in seclusion,
And who are the remainder of the True Dhamma,
When the defilements increase,
They invade the many people,
As if the fools are playing with
The demons, as if they were mad.
Those who are overcome by the defilements,
Run around here and there,
Men in the objects of the defilements,
As if in a battle with the enemy.
Having abandoned the True Dhamma,
And quarrelling with each other,
Following after the views,
They think: ‘This is the best.’
Wealth, children, and wife,
Having abandoned and gone forth,
For the sake of a handful of alms,
They are not satisfied with what is insufficient.
After eating a meal that makes them sick,
they lie down on their left side.
When they wake up, they talk about
the kind of talk the Teacher has criticized.
All kinds of crafts and skills
they learn with their minds focused.
Not being calm within,

analyzed: sāmaññatthaḥ uti acchati  mattikam tela cuṇṇam ca
translated: they claim it’s for the sake of the monastic life.🔽Clay, oil, and powder,
water, seats, and food
they offer to the laity,

analyzed: ākaṅkhantā bahuttara  dantaponam kapittham ca  puppham khādaniyāni ca
translated: hoping for much in return.🔽Tooth cleaners, wood-apple fruit,🔽flowers, and fresh food,
and when the almsfood is finished,
mangoes and emblic myrobalan.
Just as doctors prescribe medicine,🔽just as householders do what should and shouldn’t be done,

analyzed: kicca akicce yathā gihī  gaṇikā ava vibhūsāya
translated: just as a prostitute adorns herself,
just as the aristocracy are the rulers.
They’re dishonest and deceitful,
false witnesses and unreliable.
By many kinds of schemes
they enjoy material things.
By means of deception and roundabout talk,
they run around with their schemes.
For the sake of their livelihood,
they gather much wealth by trickery.
They serve the community
by action, not by the Teaching.
They teach the Teaching to others,
They quarrel over gains, not over the Dhamma.
They quarrel over the gains of the Sangha,
and are excluded from the Sangha.
Living off the gains of others,
they have no shame or conscience.
Some are not devoted to the Buddha,
but have their heads shaven and wear the outer robe.
They seek to be respected,

analyzed: lābha sakkāra mucchitā  evam na an appayātamhi
translated: deluded by gains and honors.

original: na dāni sukaraṁ tathā;🔽Aphusitaṁ vā phusituṁ,
analyzed: na sukaram tathā  a phusitam vā phusitu
translated: When it’s like this, it’s not easy🔽to touch what hasn’t been touched before,
or to preserve what has been touched.
Just as one would walk in a place with thorns
without hurting one’s feet,

original: evaṁ gāme munī care.🔽Saritvā pubbake yogī,
analyzed: evam gāme munī care  saritvā pubbake yogī
translated: so one should live in a village🔽with mindfulness well established.
Remembering the yogis of the past🔽and following their example,
even if it’s the last of times,
one may touch the deathless state.
After saying this, in the Sālatree Wood,
the monk with developed faculties,
the brahmin, attained complete extinguishment,
the sage, whose future births have ended.”
… the elder Pārāpariya …
The twentieth chapter is finished.🔽Here is the summary:
Adhimutta, Pārāpariya,
Telaṅkāni, and Raṭṭhapāla;
Mālukyasela, Bhaddiya,
Aṅguli, and Dibbacakkhukū.
The Pārāyanavagga has ten suttas,
in the Vīmaṁsaka is the twenty-first;🔽There are two hundred and fifty-five
verses in the Pārāyanavagga.
